news_header: A newly discovered fossil skull suggests Vegavis iaai may be the earliest known waterfowl, closely related to modern ducks and geese.
news_original_title: Earth’s first waterfowl may have lived in Antarctica 69 million years ago
news_text: Scientists have discovered a nearly complete fossilized skull of Vegavis iaai, an ancient bird that lived in Antarctica 69 million years ago. This find provides strong evidence that it is closely related to modern waterfowl like ducks and geese. The skull exhibits features such as a toothless beak and a large braincase, indicating advanced visual processing. The discovery raises questions about the evolutionary relationships of ancient birds and their traits, highlighting the complexity of classifying prehistoric species.
